Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum who was seen being grabbed in the street and strangled was later found dead - and her killer remains at large. CCTV footage showed Maria Jane Rawlings being attacked, with a dog walker then finding her body in a bush in Little Heath, Romford, in East London, around pm on Tuesday. A post-mortem then revealed the -year-old had also possibly been bludgeoned to death. A homeowneraposs security camera captured the moment Maria was dragged off the street and led to the shrubbery where her body was later found. The incident happened at around .pm, with the harrowing footage having been passed to police, Mail Online reports. It comes after detectives investigating the murder released clips and images of a man they would like to speak to. Ms Rawlings had been at Kings Georges Hospital in Goodmayes, Ilford, on Monday, before making her way on foot to Barley Lane in the direction of the A. It is believed that while walking on this road, someone may have approached her, the Met said in a statement. Detective Chief Inspector David Hillier, who is leading the murder investigation, said he would like to identy the man shown travelling on a  bus towards Dagenham at approximately .am on Tuesday in the police released footage. He said: “I would urge anyone who recognises this man to contact police immediately.We are carrying out a fast-paced investigation and I believe this man may have signicant information to help us with our enquiries. If anyone sees this man, I would ask them not to approach him but to call .” The post-mortem at Walthamstow Mortuary on Wednesday gave a preliminary cause for death as neck compression and possible blunt force head trauma.

title: converted 1970s school bus transformed
story: NewsConverted s school bus transformed into quirky holiday home with retro fittingsThe school bus was in operation in the s in Canada but is now on a secluded spot on a family-run farm near Seaton, Devon, in the UKmirrorShareCommentsByLili StebbingsBradley JollyDigital journalist:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThis s school bus has been converted into a stunning holiday home with retro fixtures and fittings. The Bluebird bus now offers an off-grid retreat for the ultimate getaway, having been in operation to transport children to school in Canada for years.The retro conversion sleeps two guests and one dog, which comes at an extra cost of £, reports Devon Live.It has been decked out with a wood burner, gas oven, hob, thermoelectric cool box, charcoal BBQ, fire pit, wet-room style shower and one double bed. This property offers an off-grid experience with no internet access although has G connection. Bluebird, which is on farmland near a vineyard in Seaton, Devon, is a short drive to popular tourist destinations. These include Jurassic Coast and several beaches. It is also within two miles and shops and pubs are within walking distance. Other attractions and places of interest include the market town of Axminster, Axe Valley Wildle Park, The Donkey Sanctuary, Lyme Regis Museum and Marine Aquarium, Seaton Tramway and numerous National Trust properties.  Private off-road parking for one car is provided. A seven-night stay at the Bluebird bus starts from £ and is being advertised on holidaycottages with availability throughout the summer months. The advert says: Step inside this beautully converted s former Canadian school bus and you will firstly find the surprisingly light and spacious living area. Here a comfortable lounge area is located beside a warming wood burner, and the intimate dining area provides a lovely venue for a laid-back meal at the end of the day.

title: dad who appeared ordinary actually
story: NewsOrdinary British dad-of-three is actually Colombian cartels chief drug dealerThomas Maher bragged in EncroChat messages about being involved in organised crime for over  years, when he shipped tonnes of drugs and tens of millions of pounds around EuropemirrorShareCommentsByTom DuffyEmma Grimshaw:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThomas Maher admitted drugs trafficking and money laundering " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA dad-of-three who lived a seemingly ordinary le has been exposed as a chief drug dealer in the aposhighest criminal circlesapos of international gangs. Thomas Maher appeared to be another successful businessman with a taste for nice cars and flash jewellery.But an international probe by officers at National Crime Agency uncovered his links to dealers in Colombia and Europe, reports the Liverpool Echo. Just before he was caught, he sent messages to gang members talking about fleeing the country and starting a new le in Cyrus, where there is no extradition treaty with the UK. He bragged in EncroChat messages about being involved in organised crime for over  years, during which time it’s highly likely he shipped tonnes of drugs and tens of millions of pounds around Europe. Maher first came to the attention of the NCA after police discovered the bodies of  dead Vietnamese migrants who had asphyxiated in the back of a lorry registered in his name. Although officers were unable to charge Maher in relation to the deaths, the NCA then became interested in his affairs. Maher, who ran a haulage business, lived in a modest home in the suburbs of Warrington. He had a taste for fast food and loved taking his family out for nice meals and posing for selfies. The NCA has now provided transcripts of messages Maher sent on the EncroChat network, which reveal the degree of his involvement in the drug trade. Maher was jailed for  years as a result of a massive police operation which allowed investigators to read messages on the EncroChat phone network - used by established criminals.Maher, who used the Encro handle Satirical, discussed moving cocaine out of Colombia, where the drug is sourced. In a series of messages, he talked about how the pandemic had stopped some of his drug deals from going through.  In another section of messages, Maher talked about the presence of rival crime factions in Sweden, and business opportunities in China, saying there was aposmassive money over thereapos. He later discussed another gang member who had been jailed as a result of a NCA-led investigation into his tax affairs. Maher worried about the pressure from the NCA in the UK and talks about fleeing the country.  He said: Mate look at a lot of cases here and big players in their eyes normally itaposs only conspiracy they get done on and can get big time. Thataposs why here is the worst place in the world for conspiracy laws and at home didnapost have them laws until last two or three years they brought it in. He added: Itaposs mad mate, I donapost know him I never met him the b fella but ya f****** feel for the c*** in away probably always played it right slipped up on the tazzer and now then this been thrown at him.  Thataposs why Iaposm saying once I get clear on this sort my tax bill Iaposm away mate because all they would need is to get a conspiracy on me for something. Maheraposs role in the global drug trade became clear when police in Europe managed to penetrate the Encrochat network that he relied on to communicate with associates. On June  last year Maher, then , was arrested at his Warrington home during a raid by the NCA. He later pleaded guilty to two charges relating to importing Class A drugs into the UK and two charges of money laundering.  Maher, originally from Ireland, was jailed for  years during a hearing last December for drug and money laundering offences. After Maher was sentenced in December last year senior officers at the NCA spoke about the role he played as a logistics man who helped notorious crime groups.

title: delivery mans rapid covid test
story: AdvertorialDelivery mans rapid Covid test outside hospice could have saved livesRegular rapid testing at home is a quick and easy way to help stop the spread of Covid- and protect the people around youmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialRegular testing now seen as vital to stop the spread of Covid-Alex had no symptoms when he tested positive for Covid- back in February. Around a third of people with coronavirus show no symptoms, so can infect others without even knowing they’ve been ill. Rapid testing is a vital tool to make sure people know when to self isolate so they break the chain of transmission. Alex, , from Hemel Hempstead, works for JamVans, a removal company that provides Covid- tests for its employees. He was experiencing no symptoms at all when he tested positive for Covid. “We move people’s homes on a daily basis, and also have a delivery contract with a local hospice – it has about  charity stores, and we help them move all the stock,” says Alex. “One morning before work I did a rapid Covid- test outside the hospice, then sat in my van waiting for the results. I’d done a few of these tests, and thought it would be fine as I didn’t have a single symptom – but then the test came back positive.”  “I spoke to the hospice on the phone from outside the building, and they told me I had to go for a PCR test. My company booked me in with a private firm and I went straight there. Our company policy is that we have to wear a mask in people’s houses and throughout our offices, and I stick to the guidelines as much as I can, so at first I thought the rapid flow test must be wrong. But within an hour, I was told I definitely had Covid. I couldn’t quite believe it.” Alex was able to isolate straightaway, ensuring he wasn’t spreading Covid to any vulnerable people he came into contact with. “I stopped working to self-isolate on full pay, and still didn’t develop any symptoms at all,” he says. “Without the test, I definitely would have carried on working, which is why it’s so important to have regular tests, evenyou haven’t got any symptoms. I had the virus and I felt fine, but imagineI’d given it to my parents, my grandparents or my colleagues  “If I’m driving between  charity shops, with three or four people in each shop, I could have been quite a spreader. I would have put a lot of people at risk, who may not be as young and healthy as I am – you never know who you’re passing it on to. It might sound dramatic, but in my case, taking the test could have saved lives. I haven’t had the jab yet, but I will as soon as I can – and I’ll still be taking two tests a week.Get into the testing habit More than half the adults in the UK have had at least one dose of Covid vaccination and lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease. But the virus is still out there and around a third of all the people who are infected do not show any symptoms. Regular rapid testing is vital to break the chain of transmission – now all adults are advised to do two tests a week. Rapid testing kits are free and you can do them at home, with results appearing within just  minutes. If you test positive, you’ll be able to isolate straightaway rather than risk spreading Covid to others. Millions of people have already made regular home testing part of their routine, as secondary school children and their parents have been able get free tests since February, but now everyone is encouraged to play their part. Every test helps to put your mind at rest and helps protect people around you as the country moves out of lockdown. Around one in three people with coronavirus has no symptoms. Rapid Covid-tests are for people who aren’t showing symptoms. If you’re showing symptoms , order a PCR test. Test twice a week, or every three or four days: it’s the best way to catch a case of Covid- at the point it becomes highly infectious.If you test positive you should self-isolate immediately and visit nhs.uk get-tested or call  to order a PCR test that will confirm the result.If you test negative, you must still follow the Hands, Face, Space and Fresh Air rules to minimise the spread of Covid-. Rapid tests are easy to use and give results within  minutes. It’s important to report your results online straightaway, whether the test is positive, negative or even void. It’s easy to do at gov.uk report-covid-result or by calling .More than m rapid tests have been taken since October , and hundreds of thousands of positive cases among people with no symptoms have been picked up. Information from the rapid tests is kept anonymous, and scientists use it to spot patterns and outbreaks more quickly and accurately, helping to reduce the risk of future lockdowns. Even though you might have already had one or two doses of vaccine, there’s a chance you could still give Covid to someone , as no vaccine is  per cent effective. So it’s vital to test twice weekly as well as continuing to follow social distancing guidance, washing hands, wearing a face covering and letting fresh air in. Rapid Covid- tests are suitableyou have no symptoms of Covid .“Remember, around a third of people with coronavirus have no symptoms, but could be spreading it to others without knowing,” says GP Dr Amir Khan. “Rapid testing is effective at detecting people who are infectious and enabling us to find Covid- cases that we otherwise would not know about. This helps us in our efforts to stop the spread of the virus. Testing regularly even when you have no symptoms means we can keep infection levels low and our country safe, and the good thing is they give a result within  minutes.” And, as Dr Khan notes, the tests are very reliableyou do them correctly. “Testing ourselves for coronavirus using rapid Covid- tests is vital in keeping ourselves and others safe from coronavirus and keeping infection rates in our communities low. When done correctly, the tests are at least . per cent specic, which means the risk of  positives is extremely low – less than one in a thousand. This means it is a very good test.”‘All I had was a mild sore throat’ Kim Tobin, from Southend, Essex, works in a supermarket and had a positive Covid- test in January  Routine rapid testing in the workplace helped Kim, , discover she had Covid, even though she was showing no symptoms. Without the test, she could have spread it to her workmates and customers.“I had a very, very mild sore throat, just a little scratch and that was it,” she says. “I didn’t even think anything of it. I was all dressed for work, ready to go. Then I went and had the test, and after  minutes the lady who had done it came up to me and said, ‘You need to go home right now because you’ve got it – you’ve tested positive.’”

title: family beautiful mum 33 who
story: NewsFamily of beautul mum, , who died in crash on M say le has stood stillNatalie Doherty, , lost control of her car on the M near Bury, Greater Manchester - she leaves behind her six-year-old son BobbymirrorShareCommentsByPaige Oldfield:,  MAY NewsNatalie Doherty with six-year-old son Bobby " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe grieving family of a “beautul” mum who died in a crash on the M say “le has stood still”. Natalie Doherty, , lost control of her vehicle on the motorway near Bury on Saturday afternoon. She had just joined the road when her car hit floodwater, aquaplaned, left the carriageway and crashed into a tree. Tragically, she was pronounced dead at the scene, leaving behind her six-year-old son Bobby.Speaking to the Manchester Evening News, family members have said it doesnapost feel real.She hasn’t lived her le, they said, heartbroken. Last night, Natalie’s mother, Marion Mckenzie, lay awake clutching a photo of her only child. The family said they “just knew” something was wrong when they didn’t hear from her for several hours. Then, at .pm, they received a phone call that would change their lives forever. Speaking to the MEN, Marion described the moment she found out her daughter had died. The -year-old became emotional as she said: “I screamed and Bobby said, ‘What’s wrong with nana ’ “We told him I had stubbed my toe. “Then Bobby sat on his bed with his McDonald’s watching telly.  “This morning, I realised we will never see her again. “We will never speak to her. “You just think to yourself, why did she have to go  Why didn’t she just stay at home  Why didn’t they go in the van  “But you could question everything.” Her inconsolable family have since come together to pay tribute to the “stunning” mum-of-one, who they say had a “heart of gold”. “Le has been horrendous. It’s like le has stood still,” Marion’s partner, Andrea Mckenzie, said. “Time has stopped and it’s not real. “I can’t imagine what Marion is going through. It’s her only child. “She hasn’t lived her le. She hasn’t lived her le with Bobby – and you should never have to bury your own children. “Marion just lay there with tears streaming down her face. She didn’t even shut her eyes. “She just had a picture of Natalie and herself in her hands, clutching it, and there’s nothing I can do.”  Natalie had grown up in Haslingden in Rossendale but lived in Crawshawbooth near Rawtenstall at the time of her death. She had attended secondary school in Rochdale before going on to work as a dental nurse for  years, her latest job being a receptionist at a dental practice. Her family say she loved food, shopping and visiting beauty salons, but most of all being a mother to her young son. Bobby was meant to be travelling in the car with Natalie at the time of the crash but wanted to stay at his grandmother’s house instead. Andrea continued: “He’s six – his dad told him mummy is an angel and that god only takes the good angels. “I’ve never seen a bond like the bond with her and Bobby they were absolutely inseparable. “She said she would pick Bobby up but he wanted to stay with his nana, thank God. “We didn’t hear anything because she usually rings to FaceTime with Bobby. “We didn’t hear anything and we just knew. “It got to pm and we knew something wasn’t quite right. At .pm we got the phone call.” Natalie’s cousin, Debra Wainwright, described her passing as a “massive loss”. She said: “I was brought up with Natalie and she’s more like a sister to me than a cousin. “She was really close to my mum and loved going to aunty Ann’s for a Sunday lunch. “We are a very close-knit family and it’s a massive, massive loss.” The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. title: first time mum 32 told
story: NewsFirst-time mum, , told tiny lb oz baby born at  weeks had % survival chanceLittle Oscar Dunn was born at only  weeks and his anxious mum and dad Carly and Mark, aged , were told that he had just a % chance of survival and spent four months on a neonatal ICUmirrorShareCommentsByNicole Goodwin:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCarly and Mark Dunn from Seaham with their son Oscar who was premature at  weeks " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeWhen Oscar Dunn was born at  weeks gestation, weighing just lb oz, he was given around a % chance of survival.The first time Carly and Mark got to see their newborn son, he was bright red, lying in an incubator and connected to a ventilatorforcing air into his lungs, as he wasnapost strong enough to breathe on his own.He remained in an incubator on a neonatal intensive care unitfor the first four months of his le, where his parents could only visit him up to two hours a day. But now first-time parents Cary and Mark, both , are overjoyed to have their baby boy at home and thriving after a rollercoaster year. Carly, from Seaham, told Chronicle Live: When we heard those words that he could finally come home I burst into tears. I had to stay in the hospital overnight the night before and I just couldnapost sleep. I was nervous because heaposd never been in the same room as me alone, where I would fully take care of him - change his nappies, give him his feeds. But all I could think was aposyouaposre coming home tomorrow, youaposre finally coming home with us.apos And when we eventually got home, me and Mark both cried because we couldnapost believe that the time had come for him to be at home with us.Oscar was born on June , at  weeks and one day gestation, after a blood test at  weeks found that Carly had a high blood pressure and severe pre-eclampsia.Carly had become concerned that she couldnapost feel her baby move and she remained at Sunderland Royal Hospital for two weeks, where she received daily scans to monitor her baby.  When one scan showed that blood flow had become severely restricted in the umbilical cord, Carly was blue-lighted to James Cook University Hospital, in Middlesbrough, as there were no neonatal beds available in Sunderland. Oscar was born by C-section and swtly transferred to the hospitalaposs NICU, where he spent two-and-a-half months, before ing to Sunderland for further treatment. Carly, who works as an electrician, said: Itaposs quite a shock when you walk into the NICU and hear all of the beeps and sounds of the ventilators and see your little baby in an incubator. The worst part is knowing how poorly your little baby is and not being able to do anything about it and not being able to be by hisside.Due to coronavirus restrictions, Carly and Mark could only visit Oscar for two hours a day, wearing full PPE.Every evening, when Mark finished work as an engineer, the couple would make the -mile round trip to see their son. Carly added: You just wanted to be a mam to your baby, but because of Covid restrictions you couldnapost - it was only for those two hours a day. His grandparents were also unable to visit their grandson, to prevent risk of infection in the hospital, until Oscaraposs health deteriorated when he was four weeks old.Carly received a call from the hospital to askshe would like to come into the hospital early and was later askedshe would likeOscaraposs grandparents to meet him for the first time.The couple knew there was a high chance that they could lose their son, but it was a question they were too scared to ask staff. Carly said: We both had an idea what was going on, but we were too scared to ask the question, aposhow bad is it apos Mark added: I knew I needed to ask, aposhow bad is it apos I asked [and the consultant] replied, aposItaposs very bad, we have got you a flat just next to the unit and you can invite the grandparents to see him.  aposThe next few hours will be make or break but we will do our best.apos Fortunately for the family, one consultant askedhe could try one last attempt at saving Oscaraposs le with hand ventilation. The couple went to bed that night hoping they didnapost get a knock on the door from a nurse, but thanks to the consultantaposs attempts to save Oscar, he is now a happy, thriving -month-old. Oscar was allowed tohome from hospital in October, aged four months. He now weighs lb oz and has recently started to fit into six to nine month clothing. Carly added: It has been such a hard, rollercoaster of a journey. One minute youaposre on a high when you see him doing well, but then the next minute it just changes and you hit rock bottom because something has gone wrong. I think a lot of people donapost realise that thereaposs this little community called the NICU. People think that pregnancy is pregnancy and at the end of it you have a lovely, healthy little baby, but for us that wasnapost the case.  She added: Oscar is a little fighter, heaposs so strong. Heaposs so lovely and heaposs doing all the things that he should be doing for his age now. Heaposs so cheeky and heaposs got such a lovely personality. He was known as aposthe feisty oneapos at James Cook because all the nurses used to keep diaries on the babies in the NICU. They would write what the baby has been up to and every time we read it the nurses would have written aposOscaraposs been feisty again today and trying to pull his tubes out.apos Carly and Mark say they are lucky that there was technology to help them to stay updated on Oscaraposs development, especially while they couldnapost be at the hospital. And they are incredibly thankful to nursing staff and the Neoangels charity, who support families with premature babies, for their efforts to keep them in contact with their baby. Carly said: Weaposd often get pictures from the nurses of Oscar with a message saying aposnight night mummy and daddy, love you,apos or aposcan’t wait to see you tomorrow.apos And youaposd get pictures of him doing things like sticking his tongue out. title: holidays blow rapid free tests
story: NewsHolidays blow as rapid free tests may not be enough proof for ing BritsBookings to a number of countries, including Portugal, have soared after a green list of  countries where UK travellers can go to without quarantine was revealedmirrorShareCommentsByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  MAY NewsForeign travel will be allowed again from May  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSun-seeking tourists have been dealt a blow after reports claim free lateral flow tests may not be approved for travellers ing from green list countries. Bookings to a number of countries, including Portugal, have soared after a green list of  countries where UK travellers can go to without quarantine was revealed. But Brits ing to England will still have to show a negative Covid test taken up to  hours before travel. Whitehall sources had previously said that travellers will be given free lateral flow tests to pack in their suitcase for thejourney. Now, the Dailyreports that the free testing equipment may not now be allowed for use by May  after a failure to reach “cross-Government agreement” on the scheme. It comes amid concerns about validating the test results which are self-administered by travellers as well as their accuracy. A source was reported to have said: “It is more about the implementation than the science. How do you check the results  How do you validate them  Do people just turn up and show them ” A Department for Transport spokesman was reported to have said it was “working with the travel industry and private testing providers ahead of international travel reopening, to see how we can further reduce the cost of travel for the British public, while ensuring travel is as safe as possible.

will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTo mark the start of Mental Health Awareness Week, the British Asian Trust and CareTech Foundation are jointly urging the British-Pakistani population to recognise and de-stigmatise mental health within their communities. I wholly support this initiative. With my own Asian background, I have experienced first-hand the devastating affect mental health has on people when it is a taboo subject – misunderstood, ignored and brushed under the carpet. We cannot allow this situation to carry on because not recognising the importance of mental health has a wider impact on all society. My parents and countless other first-generation British Pakistanis grew up in a culture that doesn’t acknowledge mental health. I remember my own trauma when I realised I might be made to marry someone my parents chose for me. What do you think  Have your say in comments below  It consumed my thoughts as an -year-old. I couldn’t talk to my parents about it because they would have been ashamed of me, and I couldn’t talk to my teachers and friends because they didn’t understand my culture. So I had no outlet for those feelings of fear, anxiety, anger and helplessness. Shockingly, in Pakistan, families often turn to spiritual healers, who associate mental illness with supernatural forces such as witchcraft, possession and black magic.  A child showing signs of misbehaviour or a woman not adhering to the cultural norms would be taken to one of these healers to rid them of the “gin” or evil spirit. The UK has accessible mental health services with more than , registered therapy professionals. Yet many in the UK’s Pakistani communities don’t reach out for help for fear of judgement. In one UK study, middle-aged Pakistani men and older Indian and Pakistani women reported signicantly higher rates of depression than white people. It angers me that the western-educated Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan has not used his  to address the mental health of his population, which could in turn have a positive impact on the Asian community here in the UK. title: majority parents think covid pandemic
story: NewsMajority of parents think Covid pandemic had negative impact on children, study findsResearchers polled  mums and dads and found  per cent have observed higher levels of anxiety in their kids during lockdown, with more mood swingsmirrorShareCommentsByRob Knight:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMore children are suffering from anxiety, according to parents in the poll"Join the lockdown community for surveys on your viewsInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThree quarters of parents believe the pandemic has had a negative impact on their childaposs mental wellbeing, according to a study. Researchers polled  mums and dads, of children aged  to , and found  per cent have observed higher levels of anxiety in their kids during lockdown. A thirdhave witnessed an increase in mood swings and  per cent noticed a deterioration in their confidence over the past year or so. This may have had a knock-on impact on educational development too, as six in  parents believe their childrenaposs ability to learn has been affected, especially with regards to reading. The research was commissioned by insurers MORE THAN, which has partnered with charity Dogs for Good, to highlight how dogs can improve kidaposs confidence, wellbeing and ability to learn and read. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section... DJ and presenter Jo Whiley has been helping to shows just how our canine friends can help read classic kidaposs book, The Story of Doctor Dolittle, accompanied by a furry friend to encourage children to pick up a book. Jo said: Thereaposs something incredibly soothing about sitting with a dog and just being tactile - stroking the dog and just feeling the warmth that comes from them.  And I think thataposs why itaposs very important to read with your dogs - it actually does help. A separate study of , parents, commissioned by the charity and insurers, also found four in said their kids have become less confident readers during the past  months or so. While  per cent think their reading age has stagnated in the wake of the pandemic and  per cent have noticed their kids find it harder to focus when reading. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Michael Sheen has joined the Archbishop of Canterbury to support the call for a national Thank You Day.A campaign is asking the public to get together on July  and thank the people who have helped them over the pandemic. To get the ball rolling, Justin Welby, the Archbishop of Canterbury, said: “I want to thank the person who has been caring for my mother over the past year. She has been so generous with her time and spirit and care.” Meanwhile, actor Michael Sheen wanted to thank a special family member. He said: “I want to say thank you to our little daughter Lyra who has spent most of her le in lockdown. Thank you Lyra for keeping us busy and sleep deprived.” Other stars backing the cause are Bear Grylls, Ellie Simmonds and Ainsley Harriot. Visit the website for the Thank You Day campaign here The day is being backed by the Mirror and we are asking readers to send in their nominations for their local heroes and why they want to say thank you to them. The idea for Thank You Day was proposed by a small group of people from across the UK including May Parsons, the nurse who delivered the UK’s first COVID vaccination jab in Coventry in December. May said: “Thank You Day gives me the opportunity to thank all my amazing colleagues working in the NHS and social care.  “This has been the toughest year of our professional careers, and you have all worked so hard to treat all the sick patients who came through our doors, while delivery the biggest and most successful vaccination programme in NHS history.” She added: “I am so grateful to all the people who kept us going: the school teams who looked after our children, shop staff, transport and delivery workers, and everyone  who has helped keep us and the country going. We couldn’t have done it without you.” In an open invitation to the public, the proposers – many of whom are part of the campaigning Together coalition - have said: “Covid- has had a devastating impact on so many people, and it’s tested us in ways we never expected. But for many of us, it has also bought us closer together. Closer to our families and to our communities. “As a country we aren’t always great at saying thank you to each other. But this year we want to be part of changing that.  “To choose one day where we all pause to say thank you to each other. To remember what binds us together, not just what pushes us apart. “We all have dferent people to thank, from family members to key workers, good neighbours to volunteers.

title: miracle dog survives 400ft plunge
story: NewsMiracle dog survives ft plunge as fisherman finds pooch at bottom of clfThe five-year-old Lakeland Patterdale terrier cross, named Frank, was found at the bottom of clfs by a fisherman at Cayton Bay, ScarboroughmirrorShareCommentsBySamantha Yule:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsIncredibly terrier Frank survived the ft fall and was found by a fisherman " %, rgba, rgba, url"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe overjoyed owners of a pet dog have voiced their disbelief after he survived a ft clf fall. Miracle pooch Frank plunged down the rugged clf face in Yorkshire as frantic Stewart Wragg searched for him. Frank, a five-year-old Lakeland Patterdale terrier cross, was found by a fisherman at Cayton Bay, Scarborough. He is recovering at home after the shocking deal, which left him with broken front and back left legs and missing teeth. Stunned Stewart said: If he were a human, he would have been dead. He has fallen and landed flat on his left-hand side. Somebody was looking down on him that day because how he has survived that fall, I donapost know. Not only did Frank endure the drop after falling onto the rocks below the clfs at Cayton Bay, Scarborough, North Yorks., but it is a stroke of luck that he was even found ` by a lone fisherman looking for good fishing spots while the tide was coming in. If he had not been found then, he would have been taken out to sea. Frank is now recovering at home in the village of Marsh Lane, Derbys., after having £, worth of vet care which has seen him have one broken leg repaired and his back knee rebuilt with polycarbonate. The accident happened last month when -year-old builder, Stewart, was on holiday with his ex-partner, Allison Howe, , and their son, Ewan, seven. Keen walker Stewart met up with friends to walk the Cleveland Way ` a North Yorkshire -mile walk from Helmsley to Filey.  Frank, his trusty sidekick, who has accompanied him on all his walks, from the Hebridean Way to the Munro mountains of Scotland, was loyally by his side. The father-of-three was embarking on the leg that goes between Scarborough and Filey ` across steep ft clftops - marked with stark warnings - when he noticed at midday that Frank had disappeared. In an unusual twist Frank went missing on a part of the expedition called Frank Clf. The height there is bigger than a football pitch ` which is ft long. Concerned Stewart said: We were at the highest point on the walk, but it didnapost even enter my head that he could have gone over the edge. I suspected he had caught the scent of a rabbit and gave chase. We spent about an hour and a half looking for him when we decided we ought to move on. I was frantic with worry, but terriers are clever dogs and will usually find their way back by retracing their steps.  Stewart called the local dog warden to report Frank missing in the hopes that somebody would find him and hand him in,he didnapost find his way back to the car. But when he got back to his car .pm he wasnapost there, but his phone started ringing. His heart plummeted when Alma Veterinary Surgery in Scarborough said they had Frank in their care, and he wasnapost in a good way after falling from the clf. Stewart said: I askedI could come and get him and they told me it wasnapost as easy as that, that they still didnapost know the extent of the damage and, as he was sedated, I ought to wait until morning. I had the worst nightaposs sleep that night. I really thought I was going to lose him. I have had Frank since he was two-years-old, for three years, and he a great friend to me, to be without him would be awful. He means so much.  Stewart couldnapost believe how Frank had fallen down the clf, been found by a fisherman who had taken him from the beach, wrapped him in a towel and handed him in to the RSPCA. The dog warden contacted by Stewart had also got in touch with the RSPCA who put two and two together. Frankaposs microchip had been damaged in the fall. When I got to see Frank, it was amazing, said Stewart. He couldnapost walk and was severely injured, but he was still wagging his tail like mad. I am just so so grateful that he is alive. It could have had a very dferent ending.

title: model scarred life after woman
story: NewsModel scarred for le after woman stabs her in face with screwdriver in revenge attackWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGES Stacy Dolan, who was kned three times with a screwdriver by Sharon Mather near Wigan, Greater Manchester, suffered a puncture wound to her face in the nasty and unpleasant incidentmirrorShareCommentsByAlec WhitakerBradley JollyDigital journalist:,  MAY NewsStacy Dolan, , was kned three times with a screwdriver " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice A glamour model has been left scarred for le after she was stabbed with a screwdriver by another woman in a revenge attack.Stacy Dolan, , suffered a puncture wound to the left side of the face below the eye, a cm laceration on the left knee, and bruising and swelling to the upper right arm after the attack. She was stabbed by -year-old Sharon Mather, who had confronted her inside her own home and accused her of taking advantage of a friend who gave the victim money. Now Ms Dolan, who has posed for a string of publications including Front magazine, Twisted Edge and the Daily Sport, claims she is disfigured and can no longer pose for close up facial pictures due to a scar on her lip. The mum of two, from Wigan, Greater Manchester, said: Since the incident, it has affected my confidence and the way I am. It has made me more conscious of being alone. I now no longer use my front door to enter or leave my house. My injuries have healed but the injury to my face has left me feeling like I have nerve damage to my top lip, it feels like I always have a fat lip. There is still a slight scar that can be seen close up but can be covered with makeup. However, I am aware of the fact that I have this scar and I am now really conscious of it. I am also conscious of how this has affected my modelling career and I know now that I can no longer accept work that requires me to have close up face shots. I have two small scars on my leg that I am conscious of. I also feel the scar on my face may have lost me work.  Mather, a former carer, was jailed for five and a half years at Bolton Crown Court after she was convicted of causing grievous bodily harm with intent. The jury heard Mather was drunk and angry when she repeatedly attacked Ms Dolan in Wigan, while one of the victimaposs young kids slept upstairs. Sentencing the thug, judge Miss Recorder Alexandra Simmonds told her: You were intent on remonstrating with Miss Dolan because you thought she had taken advantage of a friend of yours. It seemed you were drunk and angry and you started arguing with some money which she had taken from your friend. Miss Dolan did not know what you were talking about at first and wanted you to leave. The two of you had been friends before this night, but something had clearly upset you. The state you were in meant you were not prepared to listen to her. You had a screwdriver in your hand, you struck out at her several times causing three wounds. It was the final injury to her face that perhaps brought you to your senses as you then fled the property, realising what a terrible thing you had done. Miss Dolan sought help from a neighbour and the police were called yet you roamed the streets and ended up at the house of an elderly gentleman who you had cared for in the past. He was extremely concerned about the state that you were in and he thought you had taken drugs or been very drunk. You told him that you had stabbed Miss Dolan and at first, he didnapost believe you. He advised you to go to the police, but you didnapost. Instead, you left his house and hid at a friendaposs house. You turned yourself in a few days later, your friend was concerned you might commit suicide. Miss Dolan is more conscious about being alone in the house, while her injuries have healed, she has some altered sensation in her top lip and there is a slight scar from her face, which she is conscious of because of her modelling career. It is clear you regret your decision to go round to Miss Dolanaposs house that night and I am prepared to accept that your behaviour that night was wholly out of character - almost certainly having been affected by the alcohol you had drank that night. You are going to find the prison environment very dficult to cope with given your mental health dficulties.  The jury heard Ms Dolan and Mather fell out in July  when Mather believed Miss Dolan had taken money from a mutual friend. In the early hours of July  that year, Mather went round to Ms Dolanaposs home and the attack followed. As the victim ran to a neighbouraposs home for help, Mather fled the scene and went to the home of an elderly man she previously cared for and confessed she had stabbed the victim. He advised her to go to police but Mather instead hit at another friendaposs house before surrendering to police a few days later. She later denied wrongdoing. Katie Jones, prosecuting, said: This was a sustained assault on one victim who sustained three injuries. There were children present, but they were asleep upstairs. The offence was committed whilst the defendant was drunk or possibly high. At the time Miss Dolan had been starting out in her modelling career.

use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA -year-old musician claims he was told to leave a pubhe couldnapost control his Touretteaposs syndrome. Steve Ley, from Devon, says he was in a pub having a drink with a friend one afternoon when the landlady asked him to aposcontrolapos his behaviour because there were children around. He claims he was told to try and be quiet and on his best behaviour and thathe was bad he would have to get out. Steve says he explained he cannot control it because itaposs a medical condition, and now he wants to educate others too.He told Plymouth Live he encounters discrimination on a regular basis.His latest experience has prompted him to post a video on social media calling for people to be better educated about Touretteaposs syndrome, a condition that causes a person to make involuntary sounds and movements called tics. Carpenter Steve, who has chosen not to identy the pub in question, recalled: It was a beautul day and I was really happy to be out. I have drunk in there before but the landlady came over and was really rude and patronising to me. I was asked to control my Touretteaposs and to apostry and be quiet and on my best behaviourapos, and apos I was badapos I would have to get out. I explained I canapost control it and that it just comes out. I also pointed out what she was saying was discrimination because I have a medical condition which I canapost help. She then would not serve me so my friend got me another drink. I was able to stay. He added: I donapost want to name the pub I just want to educate people. Killing it with kindness gets you a bit further in le. Children understand it better than adults sometimes.It didnapost get me down, down, but I thought I would do a video about it and post it on my Facebook page. It has already had , views. Itaposs just a bit demoralising and it shouldnapost happen. I seem to have more problems locally than I do anywhere . I know everyone is struggling at the moment and things are dficult, butyou donapost know what Touretteaposs is in this day and age then itaposs strange. I know what people hear can be quite offensive, but it does not mean I should have to leave somewhere. I donapost have a switch or a volume button. Itaposs discrimination. Steve is well-known locally for his music and also for having appeared on television such as BBC documentary MisFits Like Us. He started having symptoms of Touretteaposs syndrome when he was just six-years-old. It began with an eye twitch and then it slowly developed into vocal ticks as well. He recalled: “It got a lot worse when I was at school. The teachers and pupils didn’t really understand what it was so that made it really hard to deal with. “When I was  doctors finally diagnosed me with Touretteaposs syndrome, but by then I was getting bullied. Being at school was a really tough time for me.” As Steve got older, having Touretteaposs never got any easier, however, it was something he had to learn to deal with. He said: “Having Touretteaposs can make you feel really isolated and alone. It can make you feel anxious and depressed sometimes, and it’s something that you just can’t escape from. I constantly feel like I have to apologise for it.” One thing that helps to channel his tics is performing on stage. Steve said: “I am a singer and I often perform at local pubs and festivals. I find that performing and being on stage really helps my Touretteaposs “I like to keep busy my tics are at their worst when I am sat around doing nothing. I also have a great group of friends that help me and that I feel comfortable around.” This summer Steve is releasing an EP called Colours and the title track has already been released as a single. title: my boyfriend three years introduced
story: NewsopinionMy boyfriend of three years introduced me to his kids and then dumped meI thought we were in it for the long-haul and I got to know his kids - so I was stunned when he said it wasnt working, a reader tells Coleen NolanmirrorShareCommentsByColeen Nolan:,  MAY NewsopinionI am feeling very angry and resentful" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeDear ColeenI’ve been with my boyfriend for three years. In truth, it’s been a stop-start kind of relationship, due to him having two children with his ex, and then Covid hit.However, I thought we were in it for the long-haul and I got to know his kids, who are adorable. So I was stunned when he told me a couple of weeks ago that he didn’t think it was working and suggested I moved out of his place, but there was no rush. I moved out last week and now I feel very angry and resentful that he led me to believe he was committed – even introducing me to his children. I can’t help feeling I was just a convenient distraction until someone better came along. What do you think  Have your say in comments below How can I possibly mend my broken heart  Coleen says Ouch! Well, it will take time, so don’t put pressure on yourself to feel better. It’s OK to wallow, cry, scream into a pillow, offload to your friends and let it all out. Of course you’re going to feel hurt and angry.It sounds to me asthe relationship never really got off the ground properly for a lot of dferent reasons, but it was still three years of your le and you were invested in him and his children.It can be very hard when you also have to end relationships with a partner’s children and other family members. title: nathaniels family just three days
story: NewsNathaniels family have just three days to raise £, for le-saving operationEXCLUSIVE: Celebs including Simon Cowell, David Walliams, Katie Price, Paul O’Grady and Coleen Nolan are backing race against time to get acute myeloid leukaemia sufferer Nathaniel Nabena, , le-saving stem cell transplant he is not entitled to for free on the NHSmirrorShareCommentsByAmy SharpeSunday Mirror reporterHalina WattsEmma Pryer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSunday People readers helped raise £, for three rounds of chemo at Great Ormond Street Hospital in March to get Nathaniel in shape for the le-saving op - but time is running out" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSimon Cowell and David Walliams are backing our ­campaign to save Nathaniel Nabena – as his family race to raise £, in three days. The big-hearted Britain’s Got Talent stars have each given five-figure sums to help the nine-year-old, after we ­revealed his parents must raise £, by Wednesday for a le-saving stem cell transplant. Manchester United and Marvel fan Nathaniel is not entitled to free NHS treatment because he is not a British national.He was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia in the UK after flying here for a £, prosthetic eye fitted privately after losing it to a tumour in his home country Nigeria. Simon, , whose son Eric is seven, said: “This must be a really dficult time for Nathaniel and his parents, let’s all pray that this campaign gets Nathaniel the treatment he needs.” Comedian David, , dad to Alfred, aged eight, said: “Nathaniel is a very special little boy and we must do everything we can to ensure he gets all the treatment he needs so he can enjoy a long and happy le.”You can add to the donations to help save Nathaniel via this GoFundMe pageGenerous Sunday People readers helped raise £, earlier this year for three rounds of chemo at Great Ormond Street Hospital in March to get him in shape for the le-saving op. He responded better than consultants expected and is in remission and in a position for a transplant, using donor stem cells from an umbilical cord. Readers have helped raise another £, last week to fund transplant procedure and doctors at GOSH have kindly waived their private fees to ­reduce the cost. But there is still another £, to find. Consultants at GOSH say his cancer couldat any time and the window for a successful op while chemotherapy is keeping the cancer at bay means the cash must be raised by Wednesday.  After that, the chances of it working will be reduced, and Nathaniel’s only likely option will be palliative care. A host of stars have rallied around to support Nathaniel as the family race to raise cash. Former JLS singer Aston Merrygold, Paul O’Grady and Loose Women’s Coleen Nolan were among those backing the lad.Dad-of-two Aston, , shared the appeal with his k Instagram followers, urging them: “Please help Nathaniel’s family”.Reality star Katie Price shared a fundraising page with her . million Instagram followers and called for fans to “give Nathaniel the chance for a le”.Nathaniel said he is “so grateful” for the support from readers and celebs. He said: “Thank you all, everybody, for helping me and giving me a chance at le. God bless everybody.” His parents Ebi, , and Modupe, , have been moved to tears by the support from stars and People readers.  Ebi said: “I’ve been crying knowing that the British people have given my son another hope in le again when all hope was gone. It is like a modern day miracle. We are so grateful. “We all watch American Idol as a family and Nathaniel watches videos of Simon on TikTok. He is a big fan. To David we say, thank you so much for coming to the aid of a stranger and being a Good Samaritan. We have still got to raise three-quarters of what we need. I have not been able to sleep, I worry so much about how we are going to raise the money. It is so tough.” This week, Nathaniel had tests and saw a psychologist at GOSH ahead of the potential transplant and rested at his relatives’ home in Croydon, South London. Ebi said: “So far the test results have been wonderful. He’s in top shape, he’s doing so well. He’s been playing his video games. “He knows he’s going to be in hospital for a long time and expressed his fears in a meeting with a psychologist. We are doing our best to reassure him.” Nathaniel has already overcome a lot after having his left eye removed last September while fighting another cancer, myeloid sarcoma, in southern Nigeria. His family raised £, so he could travel with Ebi to London to have a prosthetic fitted at London’s Moorfield Eye Hospital in November. Within days of arriving Nathaniel suffered nosebleeds and a fever and was rushed to Croydon University Hospital where he was diagnosed with terminal AML, which affects around  children every year in the UK. It is so aggressive he could have died within weeks without chemo. His family were initially told the total cost of the treatment at GOSH would be up to £,.  Celebrities have voiced their concern for Nathaniel after learning of his desperate situation. Corrie legend Beverley Callard: “This little boy deserves all the help we can give him, so let’s dig deep and get him the treatment he needs to save his le”.Emmerdale’s Claire King: “Please, please help Nathaniel’s family raise £,. Stay strong, Nathaniel. We are all wishing you the very best.”Coleen Nolan, Loose Women list: “What Nathaniel is going through is every family’s worst nightmare. They are so close to the treatment he desperately needs, and the kindness of strangers can help him.”Benidorm’s Sherrie Hewson: “Every child deserves the best chance at le, and while there is hope for Nathaniel, we mustn’t give up. He has shown such bravery coming this far and now he needs a chance at the treatment that could save him. I hope everyone will get behind this courageous little boy and his family to donate and give him a future.”Samantha Giles, Hollyoaks actress: “If you can manage to donate just a pound, it could potentially save Nathaniel’s le. Thank you, thank you! You’ve done something wonderful.”Entrepreneur and presenter Saira Khan: “If we can all give a little bit, we can help to save this little boy’s le.” TV and stage star Claire Sweeney: “GOSH consultants have graciously waived their fee, but we still need to raise £, for a le-saving stem cell treatment. Please dig deep – we only have three days to save this beautul boy.” The transplant treatment is not available in his home country and he was too sick to travel. Ebi and Modupe were in despair when they first spoke to us three months ago. But Sunday People readers stepped in to raise £, for chemo which has given him a chance of surviving a transplant. Clinicians have lowered costs after Nathaniel responded better than expected to treatment and needed less chemo.  And last week we revealed consultants at GOSH have waived their private fees to help Nathaniel. The £, covers the donor stem cell transplant and the cost of care, excluding consultants fees, based on a typical inpatient admission of eight weeks and a three-month post-transplant follow-up as an outpatient. Professor Ajay Vora, a consultant paediatric haematologist at GOSH, said: “All the consultants involved in his care are working in a private ­capacity and have waived their fee because they want to help him. “Our time is not borrowed from the NHS because we are treating Nathaniel in our private service in our time.”  If enough is raised for the transplant, Nathaniel will undergo tests to begin the process on Friday, May . Doctors had hoped to have a bone marrow transplant from one of his two sisters Nadia, , and Nicole,  months. But they were not a match. Ebi said: “Even to get to this point where we may have access to treatment is a miracle. We’d given up hope.”Add to the donations to help save Nathaniel via the GoFundMe pageOperation saved Ava’s le

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice A nervous Meghan Markle channelled the Queen during her first TV appearance since the Oprah Winfrey interview, a body language expert claimed. Duchess of Sussex, , did not gesticulate a great deal during the broadcast, a pre-recorded piece for coverage of the Vax Live concert.And Judi James, a body language expert, said this reflected the style of the Queen. She added: With the bench she was sitting on looking suspiciously like a plug for her new book, Meghan’s body language at the start looked as serene and static as the large cushion beside her, but with a small self-comfort thumb-rub gesture to suggest some inner nerves, too. Hers was a floral-clad, maternal-looking charisma, low on passionate gesticulation and high on kind smiles and bump-cupping. The regal note appeared verbally too as she sat, upright and elegant, to refer to ‘My husband and I’ in the style of the Queen, but that cupping gesture that she had also used on Oprah, reminded us of her theme about daughters and woman of the future. Meghan, who is expecting her second child, spoke about issues concerning the Covid pandemic and the empowerment of women. But Judi said Meghanaposs speech was not typical of the style weaposve seen her speak in previously. Speaking to The Sun, the body language expert noted Meghan smiled towards the end of her segment, suggesting she was starting to enjoy herself but before then, she was static.While Meghan started carefully, she became more relaxed as the chat went on, Judi added. Judi also compared Meghanaposs style to Prince Harryaposs.  During the speech Meghan, who looked smart in a red floral shirt dress, also spoke about her pregnancy as she cradled her bump. She said: My husband and I are thrilled to soon be welcoming a daughter. “Itaposs a feeling of joy we share with millions of other families around the world. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here.

title: nightmare neighbour 25 ruined mums
story: NewsNightmare neighbour, , ruined mums eyesight and stabbed her own sisterLian Clayton, of St Helens, Merseyside, repeatedly punched the disabled mum in her s on her own doorstep in the horric attackmirrorShareCommentsByLauren Wise:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsLian Clayton dragged her disabled neighbour to the floor in a horric attack " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA nightmare neighbour who ruined a disabled mumaposs eyesight in a horric attack stabbed her sister in a previous offence. Lian Clayton, , repeatedly punched Karren Bradshaw, a disabled mum in her s, on her own doorstep. A court heard Clayton pinned the woman to the floor as she punched her, before beginning to kick her and stamp on her ribcage. Liverpool Echo reports Clayton was jailed for  months and three weeks for assault and burglary after a judge heard distressing details about her criminal record.When she was just , the thug stabbed her sister and was convicted of wounding in . The case was heard before a youth court, and she received a youth referral order for the attack, although no further detail was given in open court on Friday. Speaking about the attack on her neighbour, the prosecution said a witness heard the sounds of bones crunching as the woman was screaming in pain. Zahra Baqri, prosecuting, said there was some background between the neighbours, who had lived a few doors away from each other in St Helens, Merseyside. Clayton had previously confronted Mrs Bradshaw and after receiving a message from the womanaposs daughter, telling her to leave her mum alone, Clayton appeared at Mrs Bradshawaposs door and said whereaposs that fat b****** about her daughter. When Mrs Bradshaw explained she didnapost live with her daughter, Clayton punched her to the face a number of times then dragged her out of her own home whilst still punching her. The lawyer told Liverpool Crown Court: The victim lost consciousness and when she came to she was on the ground. At that point the victim was screaming for help.  Julia Boyd, another neighbour, heard the womanaposs screams and ran to the scene, where she was confronted by Clayton sat straggling over the woman having pinned her arms down with her knee while punching and screaming at her victim. Mary Clayton, the defendantaposs mother, was shouting at her daughter to get off the victim. Ms Baqri said: The neighbour tried to help but was unable to do so. All she could manage was to hold the victimaposs hand to try and comfort her. Lian Clayton proceeded to stamp on Mrs Bradshawaposs ribcage with her foot. The neighbour managed to get Mrs Bradshaw to stand and she was then taken to hospital having suffered a broken nose, extensive bruising to her face and damage to her eye which has resulted in her eyesight being ruined and her seeing spider legs across her field of vision. In an interview, Lian Clayton claimed she was acting in self defence but later admitted assault causing actual bodily harm. Mrs Bradshaw said she had been left frightened and was attacked for no reason whatsoever. Three months later, mum and daughter Mary and Lian Clayton burgled Mrs Boyd and her husband, relying on his kind-hearted nature to carry out their crime. While Mrs Boyd was in hospital receiving treatment for a fall Lian and Mary went to Mr Boydaposs home and asked for help claiming they had locked themselves out.

title: nurse who delivered worlds first
story: NewsNurse who delivered worlds first Covid vaccine backs a national Thank You DayMay Parsons, a matron at University Hospital Coventry, is part of a group of people calling for a national Thank You Day on July  - she administered the worlds first Covid jab on December mirrorShareCommentsByChiara Fiorillo:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMay Parsons administered the Pfizer vaccine to Margaret Keenan in December " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA nurse who delivered the worldaposs first coronavirus vaccine is backing a campaign to thank all the people who worked hard during the coronavirus pandemic to help each other and protect the country. May Parsons, a matron at University Hospital Coventry, is part of a group of people calling for a national Thank You Day on July . The nurse, who administered a Covid- vaccine to -year-old Margaret Keenan on December , , said Covid- has had a devastating impact on many people, but has also brought us close to each other. Ms Parsons says it is important to thank all the people - including teachers, family members, key workers and neighbours - for what they have done during the pandemic. Visit the website for the Thank You Day campaign here She said: “Thank You Day gives me the opportunity to thank all my amazing colleagues working in the NHS and social care. This has been the toughest year of our professional careers, and you have all worked so hard to treat all the sick patients who came through our doors, while delivering the biggest and most successful vaccination programme in NHS history.I also want to thank the incredible volunteers who gave up their time to support us, and those in their communities who needed help. I am so grateful to all the people who kept us going: the school teams who looked after our children, shop staff, transport and delivery workers, and everyone  who has helped keep us and the country going.We couldn’t have done it without you. I am incredibly proud of our staff and our volunteers, and I want to encourage everyone to embrace Thank You Day and to take part in any way that you can.”  The campaign to establish a Thank You Day on July  has received widespread support. It calls on people to mark the day by getting together with their neighbours, friends and family and joining in a huge nationwide thank-you. There are also plans to arrange special park runs and raising a glass or cup of tea to say Cheers for Volunteers at pm. Julie Siddiqi, a community worker from Slough and another of the day’s proposers, said: “We’re all looking forward to the end of restrictions but that doesn’t mean we all go back to ‘normal’.We can look forward to doing some things better than we did before. And we can start by saying a heartfelt thanks to each other and staying connected with our neighbours.”  The campaign has also been backed by national organisations including the Scouts, Girlguiding, Royal Voluntary Service, the FA and the Together Coalition.The event follows the huge public support for the Health Service on its nd anniversary over the same weekend last year. Catherine Johnstone, CBE, Chief Executive at Royal Voluntary Service said: “Throughout what has been an incredibly dficult year, we have been fortunate enough to have seen the best of human kindness.“Across the country, people have come together to support their communities in remarkable ways and these people deserve our heartfelt thanks. We are very proud to be supporting ‘Thank You Day’ on July  which will give us all an opportunity to show our gratitude to those who have gone above and beyond to help the country through the pandemic.It is fantastic that volunteers will be recognised during the day, as across the country, both nationally and locally, they have been pivotal in supporting our communities and the NHS. I look forward to seeing everyone on July  for a well-deserved day of thanks.” In a video released for the launch of the campaign, well-known figures have been saying who they want to thank. Justin Welby, Archbishop of Canterbury, said: “I want to thank the person who has been caring for my mother over the past year. She has been so generous with her time and spirit and care.” Actor Michael Sheen said: “I don’t want this to sound like some terrible Oscar speech but I want to say thank you to our little daughter Lyra who has spent most of her le in lockdown. Thank you Lyra for keeping us busy, and entertained and sleep-deprived.” With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. Bear Grylls, Chief Scout, said: “I’ll be saying a huge thank you to my family and to our incredible scout volunteers.” Eriona Mehmeti, who is leading the campaign in London, said: I’ve seen first-hand how many ordinary people have been doing extraordinary things to help their friends and neighbours.I want to thank everyone who’s been there for a young person when they needed that boost, and every neighbour who’s gone that extra mile to make le a little bit easier.”  Sandra McCabe, who is running the campaign in Belfast, said she has been overwhelmed by the support she has received following a family bereavement and challenges posed to her business by the pandemic. Despite the challenges, she maintains a positive outlook, saying: “I have lots of people to thank and a lot to be thankful for.”

title: one britains most wanted men
story: NewsOne of Britains most wanted men on the run for eight years arrested in Dubai stingMichael Paul Moogan, , was allegedly involved in a large-scale trafficking plot. The alleged international drug dealer from Croxteth, Liverpool, was held on April mirrorShareByPat HurstChiara Fiorillo:,  MAY NewsMichael Paul Moogan was arrested in Dubai " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeOne of Britainaposs most wanted men, who has been on the run for eight years, has been arrested in Dubai. Michael Paul Moogan, , was allegedly involved in a large-scale trafficking plot. The alleged international drug dealer from Croxteth, Liverpool, was held on April  after a joint operation between the National Crime Agency and police in Dubai. He will be ed to the UK to face trial. Details of his arrest were only made public for the first time today due to operational reasons, the NCA said. Moogan had been on the run since a raid at a Rotterdam cafe which was suspected of being used as a front for meetings between drug traffickers and cartels. It was also central to an alleged plot to bring hundreds of kilos of cocaine into the UK every week. Working with the Dutch National Crime Squad, the NCA became aware of information that linked Moogan and two other British men to the Cafe de Ketel - a business not open to the public that could only be entered via a security system. NCA officers suspected that Moogan and his alleged associates were involved in plans to import drugs from Latin America to the EU. At the time of the raid, only one of the men, Robert Hamilton, , from Manchester, could be found. He was jailed for eight years in  after pleading guilty to drug charges. The other man, Robert Gerard, , from Liverpool, handed himself in to the NCA after three years on the run, claiming the pressure was too much. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  He pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges and was jailed in  for  years. Moogan is the th person arrested under Operation Captura - an NCA fugitive campaign run in conjunction with Crimestoppers. NCA officers established that Moogan was using numerous  identities to avoid capture. Dubai Police believe that after entering the UAE using a dferent identity, he tried to avoid CCTV in an attempt to elude detectives. NCA director of investigations Nikki Holland said: This arrest is the result of years of investigation involving a range of law enforcement partners in the UK, Europe and Middle East. We are extremely grateful to those partners for their assistance in ensuring Moogan now faces justice and particularly thank the Dubai Police for their efforts to track him down.

title: queens ex head chef shares
story: NewsQueens ex-head chef shares Princess Annes unusual preference when it comes to eating bananasPrincess Diana, Prince William and Prince Harry also reportedly like to eat ripe pears by slicing off the top and eating it with a teaspoon like a boiled eggmirrorShareCommentsByBeth CruseEmma Grimshaw:,  MAY NewsPrincess Anne has an unusual preference when it comes to eating bananas " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Queenaposs former head chef has revealed Princess Anne’s unusual preference when it comes to eating bananas.Darren McGrady, who worked in the royal kitchens of Buckingham Palace from  to , also shared Princess Diana, Prince William and Prince Harryaposs bizarre habit when it comes to consuming pears, reports Bristol Live.In an interview with TODAY, he said that after a pudding course, royals like to eat fruit.Platters often include bananas, apples, pineapples, peaches, grapes and pears - and changes seasonally. But the chef revealed that the Princess Royal enjoys eating her bananas ‘almost black’.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here “Princess Anne almost always preferred the bananas almost black - over ripe - because they digested easier. Due to an aposold traditionapos, members of the Royal Family are not able to eat any item of food with their hands. This means most senior royals are forced to cut up fruit and eat it with a kne and fork, said McGrady. “They [anyone present at the royal banquet] have a dessert kne and fork, a small plate and a finger bowl of water ... which some guests have been known to drink,” said McGrady. And bananas aren’t the only fruit to receive special treatment. While McGrady was working for the royal family, serving Princess Diana, Prince William and Prince Harry, they had an unusual way of enjoying pears.“The purveyor would bring about  for us to choose the ripest by hand,” McGrady shared. Then they would slice off the top and eat it with a teaspoon like a boiled egg!”  He went on to say pineapples are ‘hollowed out,’ sliced, and put back into the pineapple so they can be eaten with a kne and fork. McGrady has previously shared that the Queen enjoys four meals a day but only eats small portions at each. The Queen is said to enjoy a cup of tea and biscuits, followed by cereal in the morning.
